memories.name: Gabe Dunn
memories.story: This one was from such a long time ago - 2011 I think. We were all in Griffith Woods scooting across the river on top of fallen tree. You had some sticks that you didn't want to put down for some reason, and everyone was yelling about how cold the river was. As we were walking back from the river we came across a random sofa in the middle of the woods and took some pictures. There were so many more good times at Griffith Woods but I could only find some pictures from this time. Those were some good times...

memories.name: Gabe Dunn
memories.story: This entire trip is full of amazing memories - Ping-pong tournaments, pool tournaments, lots of lounging around on the beach. I think you were the only one who burnt more than I did in all that sun. The amount of beach vendors that we had to fend off before finally succumbing to their marketing and getting some hand made shark tooth necklaces was too many to count. That was a great trip.

memories.name: Gabe Dunn
memories.story: This might have been the last time I went trick-or-treating. Our ensemble of superheros (Super Ryan, Super Gabe, Super Anthony, Super Enzo, and Super Breo) was certainly something (although it might have been easy to confuse us with those people who wear tinfoil hats with the amount of tinfoil we were wearing). It was great fun making those costumes, and then going out and roaming the neighborhoods with you.

memories.name: Casey
memories.story: You better believe we cared more about our hockey teams and climbing on the “do not climb” areas than looking at the animals.

memories.name: Ryan’s Aunt Donna
memories.story: This photo of Ryan in his Superman Halloween costume has always been a family favourite.  Look at the joy on that young boys face.

memories.name: Alicja Izaak's mom (and Milena's and Rachel's)
memories.story: This drawing was done in the first few days after the devastating news of Ryan's crossing over, when nothing made sense and there was ocean of deepest sadness. It helped me to just sit and draw. I had to hold back tears and focus on proportions, colour and thoughtful expression on Ryan's face.  We miss you Ryan, your words "Be kind to one another" have become my everyday motto.

memories.name: Alicja Izaak's mom (and Milena's and Rachel's)
memories.story: Grade nine play at Waldorf School: Midsummer Night's Dream and Hamlet combined. I like Ryan's humble look on this photo.

memories.name: auntie Shari.
memories.story:
When Ryan was a wee lad, like all toddlers, he was constantly told what he could and couldn’t do, with no one to boss himself. Except Campy. So it was not too surprising that his first words were dog commands. 

Pete told me one day Ryan was out playing in the yard and it was getting close to nap time. Pete stood on the deck and called to Ryan, who immediately ran away. Then he stopped, remembering he had just the words for this scenario, which were to point his tiny finger at his dad and tell him quite firmly, “NO!”  Then Ryan pointed at the grass and told dad, “Down!”  Pete said he couldn’t help but laugh. 
It’s always been one of my favourite stories.

memories.name: Auntie Shari’s memories
memories.story: The biggest cousin Justin and the littlest cousin. Justin was pretty good at tossing little kids around and making them giggle like mad.

memories.name: Auntie Shari’s memories.
memories.story: I remember Pete telling me that when he took Ryan out grocery shopping, or anywhere, people would stop and tell him what a beautiful baby boy he had.  That little triangle face was so sweet.

memories.name: Auntie Shari’s memories.
memories.story:
This Christmas i had bought Kiana this beautiful furry vest which she tossed aside with huge disappointment, finding not a thing of interest in such a big box. So I went out and got her a truck, cuz she loved all things Big brother Ryan had or did.  Her face was just open delight that I bought her a truck. That it was all for her. 
 Ryan, of course, was on hand to inspect it and determine if it would be of adequate performance for his little sis.  Then later he would get out the screw driver, take apart the engine and advise Kiana of the fine inner workings of mechanical engineering, their two little heads side by side.

memories.name: Auntie Shari
memories.story: This little face.  Jen gave this pic to all of us that Christmas. I still have it framed sitting on my desk.

memories.name: Auntie Shari
memories.story: And who knows what upset him...dad saying he couldn’t steal his glasses, or play with the axe, or it was nap time. But the expression of feelings just couldn’t possibly be more clear. I know you are all smiling right now, same as me.

memories.name: auntie Shari
memories.story: The first of 3. What happiness this little boy had, and no doubt, with all the joy and love that surrounded him.

memories.name: auntie Shari
memories.story: Bond…Ryan Bond. His spy master kit that Ryan was delighted to play with Josiah, his hero.

memories.name: anonymous
memories.story: It was a wonderful family weekend.

memories.name: auntie Shari
memories.story: I was visiting one day and Josiah came over to hang out. Ryan had been watching for him from the upstairs window and let us know when Josiah had arrived, with a squeal of happiness. Jen and I went downstairs to greet Josiah at the door and, oddly, Ryan wasn’t in front of us to get to Josiah first. He came running down the stairs and we saw he had changed his t-shirt. You see, Josiah had come to the door wearing a green t, so Ryan ran straight to his bedroom to change into his own green t. So they could be matchy matchy. It put a tear in Jen’s eye. What a kid.

memories.name: auntie Shari
memories.story: Impossible to have a book about Ryan without LEGO. He was crazy for it. I think he was about 8 when I bought him a pretty complicated kit. I knelt down to help him with it, but it was pretty evident that I would just be in the way. Ryan sure didn’t need the instruction book (which I couldn’t even understand). Thanks all the same, auntie Shari, but you are kinda in the way.….

memories.name: auntie Shari.
memories.story: Oh this little kid. He was something special. I remember Pete telling me that Ryan got this helmet for Christmas and LOVED it   He would not take it off, even to sleep. They had to ease it off his head after he was sacked right out.

memories.name: auntie Shari.
memories.story: Ryan told me last summer about going to the Stampede with Ella. He didn’t mention wearing his dad’s boots and hat, but I always picture him like this. Little character, he was.

memories.name: auntie Shari.
memories.story: Ryan loved his baby sister. I remember he worried about Kiana after she was born and had a bit of trouble. It was a big deal for him to ask dad if she was okay. And of course she was.  He was a good big brother, even when he was only tiny himself.

memories.name: anonymous
memories.story: Ryan always made sure I got included in all kinds of activities he would make sure I would never feel left out of anything despite my physical challenges. That is something that is very special to me that i'll always remember.

memories.name: Shelley E L Wright
memories.story: I have submitted a few photos from a class one trip to Eagle Feather riding stable.  Ryan's kind and gentle essence were tangible not only to us but with animals too.  We had a wonderful class connection that day.

memories.name: Shelley Wright
memories.story: A photo of Ryan from I believe his first visit with Mom and Dad in our backyard.  Parkdale neighbours at that time!  Jen befriended me on our street corner while she was walking with you and Campy.  She and Campy knew our yard as they would usually walk on the opposite side of the street to avoid Brad's (territorial) Cat - Tiger, but not this lucky day.   I was just recovering from surgery and was walking very slowly by myself pushing a double stroller with Casey and Estelle and we were just at our side door when we started chatting.  The next day the Jen arrived with a Lasagne for us.  How extremely generous and thoughtful.  And from there, as they say, the rest is history.  Your beautiful smile and soul was an easy connection for my two!

memories.name: Shelley Wright
memories.story: Opps  just realized that this other photo from Eagle Feather Ranch (Grade 1 Field Trip) didn't upload with my other post.  You were up so high on that big horse and so brave!!  We were all so impressed and thrilled for you.
